column62:
(1) The questions about software engineering did not really touch on the main issue for me, which is how to ensure that the software is 'correct' with regard to mathematical calculation and statistical methodology.

(2) As a researcher in statistics, one of my main research outputs is software which implements new methodologies that I develop. I have written over 200,000 lines of code. However, in Australia, the research funding agencies do not allow funding to be used for software development. Consequently, all my software development must be justified by its role in supporting a research publication (and the journals increasingly demand that software be supplied with the paper). There is immense pressure to do no more than is necessary for a 'proof of concept' software, but I have found that the most interesting and challenging research problems only emerge when the software is developed to full maturity. Journals which publish descriptions of software, such as the Journal of Statistical Software, have been very important in justifying my activity.

1. In academia the time spent on developing solid statistical software is not valued, I.e an article has much higher value. Writing loose software (or non at all) + an article takes much less time, hence a higher article production. Which implies that you get penalized for developing solid software.

This means that the industry typically provides very bad environments for statistical software development. Plus the industry has, in my experience, serval other issues, all meaning that the quality of the statistical software produced is low.

3. The public and some industrial managements seems to think machine learning/ statistical software can do anything. They seem completely unrealistic at times. And, importantly, forgetting to validate (or do error-prone validation of) the the machine learning system. (This is often a complicated task involving statistical and domain knowledge) The most important part of a production machine learning system is an continuous validation of the performance (the distribution of the input data is likely to change over time -- this is basic logic, but seems to be neglected or forgotten. ), a part often neglected. Meaning high risk of failure of the system, without being able to stop the system before it fails!
